===Etymology 1===
From {{etyl|km|ja|sort=きせる}} {{m|km|ខ្សៀរ|tr=khsiěrô}} or {{m|km|ខ្សៀ|tr=khsiě||a pipe for smoking}}.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref> Tobacco trade from Europe first went through Southeast Asia before reaching Japan. One source<ref>{{cite-book
|last=Suzuki
|first=Tatsuya
|title={{lang|ja|喫煙伝来史の研究}} (''Kitsuen Denraishi no Kenkyū'', “Research into the History of the Introduction of Smoking”)
|url=http://www.shibunkaku.co.jp/shuppan/shosai.php?code=4784210180
|format=[[w:A5|A5]]-sized hardbound
|accessdate=2013-06-06
|accessyear=2013
|accessmonth=June
|year=1999
|month=November
|publisher=Shibunkaku
|location=[[w:Tokyo|Tōkyō]]
|language=Japanese
|isbn=4-7842-1018-0
}}</ref> suggests that the {{etyl|km|-}} word itself was a borrowing from {{cog|es|que}} {{m|es|sorber}} or {{cog|pt|que}} {{m|pt|sorver}}, “that which is sucked upon”.

Variant readings include ''kiseri'' and ''kisero''<ref name="KDJ"/>, although these are rare.

The kanji spelling {{lang|ja|煙管}} is an example of {{ateji|sort=きせる}}.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|きせる|acc=h|dev=1|acc_ref=NHK}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|きせる|キセル}} {{ja-altread|kata=キセリ|rom=kiseri}} {{ja-altread|kata=キセロ|rom=kisero}}

# a [[tobacco]] [[pipe]] with a [[metal]] [[stem]]
# {{lb|ja|sort=きせる|slang}} a way of [[cheating]] on one's [[train]] [[fare]]
#: The train rider purchases two tickets, one for a short distance at the start of the journey, and one for a short distance at the end of the journey. In this way, the rider can avoid having to pay full fare for the total distance traveled.
#: A pun on the way that there is {{m|ja|金|tr=kane||metal; money}} on both ends, but not in the middle, similar to a ''kiseru'' pipe.
# {{lb|ja|sort=きせる|slang}} a way of [[buy]]ing [[vote]]s for an [[election]]
#: The vote buyer pays the voter part before the election and part after (assuming the election buyer wins).
#: A pun on the way that there is {{m|ja|金|tr=kane||metal; money}} on both ends, but not in the middle, similar to a ''kiseru'' pipe.
# {{lb|ja|sort=きせる|obsolete}} during the {{w|Edo period}}, someone who sold [[slow match]] to [[theater]]-goers to use to light their [[pipe]]s
